comment._content: Also - is there two Napoleons?

comment.author: 37002282@N00
comment._content: I really can't stop myself from adding this to my Favorites. What an amazing photo from ninety years ago. Just Wonderful.

comment.author: 63163769@N00
comment._content: Color this ? . . . . . . Nah!

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content:
More than fifty people in one play? It seems just a little unlikely. Maybe this is the whole company, plus the music, with maybe a few local supers as well? And perhaps the costumes represent the major part of the Murray Company wardrobe?
  But what a splendid photograph....

comment.author: 24861755@N08
comment._content: I can't believe the detail and quality of this shot for it's age.
comment.authorname: Christine Rose.., Huge Thanks To All My Flick'r Fr

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I agree with all the comments above, this is an absolute must for a favourite!  The whole range of theatrical costumes are on display here so it must have been a big event and a great opportunity to get the entire group and range captured. But what a capture?  Stupendous!!!

comment._content: Nice Photo. A lovely group of fine looking People.

comment.author: 63163769@N00
comment._content: Thank you Carol. No color other than a warm tone overall. Oh, it seems that three of the Humming Birds got into the act :-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/slimdandy] You make me laugh! Those Humming Birds get everywhere, and you've snuck them in so well, you'd never know they weren't part of the original cast.  :)
By the way, I did have a good scout around all of the faces in The Runaway Girl photo just in case any of the Humming Birds were also involved in this production, but no luck...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63163769@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] Yes, I checked the Runaway cast for Humming Birds as well; when I didn't find any, I put a few in. Messin' with history is fun.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/slimdandy] It surely is!

Checked pic of that building in our collections, and the only quibble I'd have as a location is that while the windows are similar, the top curvy bit has more ornate metalwork than on the windows of St. Michael's...

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Picture taken at the rear of city Hall/ Theatre Royal complex on the Mall in Waterford. Roof access ladder was still in situ when I worked there in 1965. Same view is still possible although new museum is being built on right hand side of pic.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Can't thank you enough for this information! Could you please check out the map if you get a moment? Fairly happy from using Street View co-ordinates that I have it spot on, but it'd be great if you could confirm this.

You have no idea how valuable your information is to us! We have tons (technical term) of Poole Collection photos taken at this spot, and it was infuriating not to know where this place was...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content:
Location as pinpointed by you on the map of Waterford city is correct. Will acquire photo of location asap and upload. Its a building site at present and access is difficult. 
The city hall/Theatre Royal complex was originally built as an Assembly Rooms to the design of John Roberts in 1783/8

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Brilliant, thank you again!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
